job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Valhalla, NY
pros: Professors are readily accessible, research is world class
cons: Weak benefits if you have a family

pros: Managers are nice Off work at 3pm on Friday from Oct to Mar
cons: under staff! because refuse to pay more, I am the assistant for two department which I supposed to be hired as for one.

pros: diverse and inclusive work-life balance accessible education is paramount and there are opportunities to receive additional skills/certification training
cons: low pay across departments very budget conscious no room for promotion/advancement

pros: The company emphasizes work/life balance!
cons: There has been no downside of working with NYMC so far.

pros: Great team to work with.
cons: Can be very stressful at times

pros: Skyline Building was the only good thing I remember about NYMC.
cons: NYMC had 100 percent employee paid dental coverage ($0.00 employer contribution) for exempt staff. Didnt like NYMC's medical benefits and retirement plans after Touro took over NYMC. I would recommend people to ask how much exempt employees need to contribute to medical plans and ask about the copayments for Dr visits. During the time I worked there, exempt staff had no annual salary increases or very low (like 1 percent) increases.

review_title: Nice place but needs a lot improvement for Reaserch
pros: An OK campus. Free parking. Some benefits
cons: Need a car for transport. can not walk can not bike. Just bus transportation or private car.

job_title: Associate Professor, Medicine in Valhalla, NY
pros: Quiet, easy, balanced, fair, resources
cons: Small, hospital, students, research, parking

job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Plains, NY
pros: Gain experience, excellent facilities very organized
cons: Location isn’t accessible and requires long commute with no reimbursement

pros: Great for entry level full-time. 100% tuition waived for graduate school. Retirement is now employer-match. Get a degree, contribute to your retirement, then move on.
cons: Terrible senior leadership. Only received one cost of living adjustment in five years, no opportunity for advancement. Health insurance is expensive and keeps increasing. Owned by Touro, so NYMC is not a priority.

pros: During the pandemic, they were good about having remote and hybrid work
cons:
No direction from leadership 
Lack of growth opportunity

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Great Benefits, good time off, great students
cons: Lots of inflated egos. You are not important if you are not a doctor.

job_title: Laboratory Technician in White Plains, NY
pros: Convenient transportation,many buses can get the school
cons: lower salaies, the benifit is not very goood

pros: After a year you are able to enroll in all but 3 of their graduate programs for free. They'll only cover 2 courses per semester, but it's better than having to pay for yourself. It's great for a middle-step on a career journey or career transition.
cons: Salary is okay at first, but after a few months the boundaries of the job extend well beyond what is fair for the salary without the addition of any financial incentives and/or rewards.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Beneficial
Good job
I started working there with no experience
cons: Low income. Busy work and many hours

job_title: Associate Dean in New York, NY
pros: Collegial environment with great co-workers
cons: Relatively low salary, lack of diversity

job_title: Research Data Analyst in Valhalla, NY
pros: Lots of holidays, snow days, and vacation time accrual.
cons: None that I could see.

pros: For a college that is going under the overall work environment was just par.  The cafe areas had decent somewhat edible food. The nicest staff was food service.  The maintenance man staff keeps the building clean and there is a lot of parking.
cons: The senior managment talked negatively about everyone, even the very nice people. There is a serious issue at this place and its going unaddressed because the college is failing and no one wants to take these positions anyways.  Be careful when you turn your back at NYMC because you might get a knife.  Numerous attempts were made to discuss unfair treatment with HR or those acting in the position of human resources.  Nothing was done to fix the problem.  This was probably the worst department to work. Not all departments were this bad from what I hear however.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Valhalla, NY
pros: friendly and family based environment, many college holidays, good starting place for a fresh PhD.
cons: No career and salary growth, no chance to get a faculty position despite having PhD, PIs are not interested in your future career and growth, basically they treat you more like a qualified laborer.  Lots of politics which is reflected in distributing intramural grants and positions. Good networking and connections needed to keep the position.

review_title: OK for a year or two
pros: Relaxed hours, some of the people you get to work with are down to earth. If you're looking to attend graduate school it's a great opportunity to work their a year and then attend their graduate school with tuition reimbursement. Good benefits.
cons: Pay low- not what you deserve for the work that you're doing. Upper management horrible, take advantage of people below them and HR doesn't do a thing about it. Overall a bit stiff.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Valhalla, NY
pros: the location is 35 mins drive from NYC
cons: Aging institution, the new touro management sucks, its all about damn money now, no scope for growth, almost 70% faculty with no public funds, most departments are dead in terms of academic activity. leaves are terrible...u accrue just one day each month from your work anniversary, maximum you can have is 12 days at the 11th month..terrible!!!! do not take a post-doc position here unless you don't have money to buy your next meal

pros: It's a small community, and I appreciated the camaraderie, and not having to worry so much about the competitiveness and back-stabbing that can take place at larger academic institutions. The people are great and the environment is chill.
cons: Resources can be limited, and tech and equipment and such can be outdated. But again, the right environment can make up for those things.

pros: Jewish Holidays off; get experience; decent pay
cons: Some of the management has horrible attitudes and horrible communication. Very little diversity. They do everything the old way...yes, they still usetypewriters every now and again. Everything is on paper. There is no real benefit to working here other than getting some experience. Definitely a place to use as a stepping stone to go somewhere else.

pros: The job is nested within the new york, metropolitan area (but is not terribly close to the city).
cons: Salaries are in the bottom 25% of northeastern medical schools and colleges; extreme vertical management; high degree of micromanagement; employee/faculty distrust. Terrible place to work. Long vesting period (20% - 2 years, 50% - 3 years, 100% - 4 years)

pros: Friendly staff. Good benefits. This is a perfect place to work if you love working in a quiet environment. The drive is beautiful coming to the campus on a daily basis.
cons: There need to be a little more organization and communication between departments. Most departments doesn't really know what the other one does.

review_title: Great experience with people around me
pros: Work-friendly environment. People are generally very helpful and would listen. There is certain diversity in faculty, which from the research standpoint can be quite beneficial.
cons: Some core facilities need improvements or updates. Cafeteria is one of the low points.

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Valhalla, NY
pros: Worked with world-class doctors and scientists on a variety of research projects aimed at improving human health by developing next generation therapies and treatments.  Gained experience using a wide variety of experimental techniques.
cons: As a student in the graduate program compensation packages were basic.

review_title: Exciting research in numerous areas.... close knit community
pros: great place to gain valuable experience for newbies...employees can attend the graduate program for free after 1 year of work.   Invaluable!!
cons: the pay is generally lower in academia but if you want to attend graduate school, the trade off is worth it.

pros:
-family oriented
-nice people and caring environment
-very good benefits
-good work hours and holiday/vacation/time off benefits
cons:
-salary levels are low but presumably in range for a university setting
-not a lot of career growth

review_title: Working at/with NYMC has been a pleasurable expereince and satisfying
job_title: Chief Affiliation Officer in New York, NY
pros: The organization is proud of it's mission to train the next generation of physicians and operated in an ethical manner in all aspects.
cons: The organizatin is in a transition period which can be difficult for current employees.

pros: The working environment is very good and there is a lot of room for growth within your job profile. All the superiors are open to suggestions and new ideas.
cons: Part time jobs should be given some perks such as meal coupons, etc.

pros: Small, close-knit community with opportunity to get to know your peers and supervisors alike. The mix of students and faculty and staff makes for a very cerebral and exciting atmosphere
cons: technology and resources can't compete with the larger institutions

review_title: Low Pay- Too Many People Want to Be In Charge
pros: PTO-Tuition Reimbursement-Great if you live in Westchester. Faculty are great to interact with.
cons: No room for growth. Some individuals have positions they should not have. Lack of communication.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Valhalla, NY
pros:
Excellent mentorship (depends on individual faculty members)
Rich work environment
Ample opportunity for collaboration with faculty within NYMC and at nearby institutions
cons: Administration not very responsive, payroll and benefits departments slow to act on requests

review_title: It was nice having work experience here ................ enjoyed tenure
pros: Relaxed work culture, religious people, ...................... easygoing
cons: Slow job growth, not many opportunities ................... take care

pros: easy to get an admit if you are locked out of all options with low entrance test scores
cons: Exam papers are leaked by previous students, Question papers keep repeating with same format. school of Health science has many international students with bogus previous degrees.

pros: small university, get chance to know many people.
cons: No sufficient funding for research available, not high level exposure

review_title: stimulating but rather a limited research environment
pros: affiliated with medical school, many researches are rather translational
cons: small graduate school with limited research labs and directions

review_title: mixed; good benefits not much else
pros: benefits; time off if it can be scheduled, holidays
cons: salary, where you begin you also end;

job_title: Medical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: great pay and the staff were great
cons: no complains it was great working there.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Friendly work environment and easy to get along with people
cons: I don't see any cons

pros: small community, open door policy and friendly colleagues
cons: limited research opportunities and limited advancement

pros: Good people, very friendly. Very quite environment.
cons: Low salary! No carrier opportunity in the research

job_title: Peer Tutor in New York, NY
pros: I got paid for the work I did.
cons: There are very few on campus jobs for students.

pros:
Nice  campus
nice working environment

pros: good exposure, dynamic research and development
